ud2.8:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kuṇḍikāyaṃ viharati kuṇḍadhānavane.
ud2.8:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kuṇḍiyā in the Kuṇḍadhāna Grove.

ud2.8:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena suppavāsā koliyadhītā satta vassāni gabbhaṃ dhāreti.
ud2.8:1.3.eng: Now at that time Suppavāsā the Koliyan had been pregnant for seven years, and in obstructed labor for seven days.
ud2.8:1.3.comm: Mūḷha here has the sense of “gone astray” in reference to obstructed labor that prevents birth; see MN 86:14.2.

ud2.8:1.4.pli: Sattāhaṃ mūḷhagabbhā sā dukkhāhi tibbāhi kharāhi kaṭukāhi vedanāhi phuṭṭhā tīhi vitakkehi adhivāseti:
ud2.8:1.4.eng: While suffering painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings, three thoughts helped her endure:

ud2.8:1.5.pli: “sammāsambuddho vata so bhagavā yo imassa evarūpassa dukkhassa pahānāya dhammaṃ deseti;
ud2.8:1.5.eng: “Oh! The Blessed One is indeed a fully awakened Buddha, who teaches the Dhamma for giving up suffering such as this.

ud2.8:1.6.pli: suppaṭipanno vata tassa bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho yo imassa evarūpassa dukkhassa pahānāya paṭipanno;
ud2.8:1.6.eng: Oh! The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is indeed practicing well, who practice for giving up suffering such as this.

ud2.8:1.7.pli: susukhaṃ vata taṃ nibbānaṃ yatthidaṃ evarūpaṃ dukkhaṃ na saṃvijjatī”ti.
ud2.8:1.7.eng: Oh! Extinguishment is so very blissful, where such suffering as this is not found.”

ud2.8:2.1.pli: Atha kho suppavāsā koliyadhītā sāmikaṃ āmantesi:

ud2.8:2.2.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, ayyaputta, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena bhagavato pāde sirasā vandāhi; appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ puccha:
ud2.8:2.2.eng: “Please, master, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Ask him if he is healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.

ud2.8:2.3.pli: ‘suppavāsā, bhante, koliyadhītā bhagavato pāde sirasā vandati; appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchatī’ti.

ud2.8:2.5.pli: ‘suppavāsā, bhante, koliyadhītā satta vassāni gabbhaṃ dhāreti.
ud2.8:2.5.eng: ‘Suppavāsā the Koliyan has been pregnant for seven years, and in obstructed labor for seven days.

ud2.8:2.6.pli: Sattāhaṃ mūḷhagabbhā sā dukkhāhi tibbāhi kharāhi kaṭukāhi vedanāhi phuṭṭhā tīhi vitakkehi adhivāseti—
ud2.8:2.6.eng: While suffering painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings, three thoughts help her endure:

ud2.8:2.7.pli: sammāsambuddho vata so bhagavā yo imassa evarūpassa dukkhassa pahānāya dhammaṃ deseti;
ud2.8:2.7.eng: “Oh! The Blessed One is indeed a fully awakened Buddha, who teaches the Dhamma for giving up suffering such as this.

ud2.8:2.8.pli: suppaṭipanno vata tassa bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho yo imassa evarūpassa dukkhassa pahānāya paṭipanno;
ud2.8:2.8.eng: Oh! The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is indeed practicing well, who practice for giving up suffering such as this.

ud2.8:2.9.pli: susukhaṃ vata taṃ nibbānaṃ yatthidaṃ evarūpaṃ dukkhaṃ na saṃvijjatī’”ti.
ud2.8:2.9.eng: Oh! Extinguishment is so very blissful, where such suffering as this is not found.”’”

ud2.8:3.1.pli: “Paraman”ti kho so koliyaputto suppavāsāya koliyadhītāya paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
ud2.8:3.1.eng: “Excellent idea,” he replied. He went to the Buddha and told him of his wife’s struggles. The Buddha said:

ud2.8:3.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho koliyaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

ud2.8:3.3.pli: “suppavāsā, bhante, koliyadhītā bhagavato pāde sirasā vandati, appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchati;

ud2.8:3.5.pli: ‘suppavāsā, bhante, koliyadhītā satta vassāni gabbhaṃ dhāreti.

ud2.8:3.6.pli: Sattāhaṃ mūḷhagabbhā sā dukkhāhi tibbāhi kharāhi kaṭukāhi vedanāhi phuṭṭhā tīhi vitakkehi adhivāseti—

ud2.8:3.7.pli: sammāsambuddho vata so bhagavā yo imassa evarūpassa dukkhassa pahānāya dhammaṃ deseti;

ud2.8:3.8.pli: suppaṭipanno vata tassa bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho yo imassa evarūpassa dukkhassa pahānāya paṭipanno;

ud2.8:3.9.pli: susukhaṃ vata nibbānaṃ yatthidaṃ evarūpaṃ dukkhaṃ na saṃvijjatī’”ti.

ud2.8:4.1.pli: “Sukhinī hotu suppavāsā koliyadhītā; arogā arogaṃ puttaṃ vijāyatū”ti.
ud2.8:4.1.eng: “May Suppavāsā the Koliyan be happy and healthy! May she give birth to a healthy child!”

ud2.8:4.2.pli: Saha vacanā ca pana bhagavato suppavāsā koliyadhītā sukhinī arogā arogaṃ puttaṃ vijāyi.
ud2.8:4.2.eng: As soon as he spoke, Suppavāsā, happy and healthy, gave birth to a healthy child.

ud2.8:5.1.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho so koliyaputto bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā yena sakaṃ gharaṃ tena paccāyāsi.
ud2.8:5.1.eng: Saying “Yes, sir,” the Koliyan gentleman approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he returned to his own house.

ud2.8:5.2.pli: Addasā kho so koliyaputto suppavāsaṃ koliyadhītaraṃ sukhiniṃ arogaṃ arogaṃ puttaṃ vijātaṃ.
ud2.8:5.2.eng: He saw that his wife, happy and healthy, had given birth to a healthy child,

ud2.8:5.4.pli: “acchariyaṃ vata bho, abbhutaṃ vata bho, tathāgatassa mahiddhikatā mahānubhāvatā, yatra hi nāmāyaṃ suppavāsā koliyadhītā saha vacanā ca pana bhagavato sukhinī arogā arogaṃ puttaṃ vijāyissatī”ti.
ud2.8:5.4.eng: “Oh lord, how incredible, how amazing! The Realized One has such psychic power and might! For as soon as he spoke, Suppavāsā, happy and healthy, gave birth to a healthy child.”

ud2.8:5.5.eng: He became uplifted and overjoyed, full of rapture and happiness.

ud2.8:6.1.pli: Atha kho suppavāsā koliyadhītā sāmikaṃ āmantesi:

ud2.8:6.2.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, ayyaputta, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena bhagavato pāde sirasā vandāhi:
ud2.8:6.2.eng: “Please, master, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet.

ud2.8:6.3.pli: ‘suppavāsā, bhante, koliyadhītā bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatī’ti;

ud2.8:6.5.pli: ‘suppavāsā, bhante, koliyadhītā satta vassāni gabbhaṃ dhāreti.
ud2.8:6.5.eng: ‘Suppavāsā the Koliyan, who was pregnant for seven years, and in obstructed labor for seven days,

ud2.8:6.6.pli: Sattāhaṃ mūḷhagabbhā sā etarahi sukhinī arogā arogaṃ puttaṃ vijātā.
ud2.8:6.6.eng: is now happy and healthy and has given birth to a healthy child.

ud2.8:6.7.pli: Sā sattāhaṃ buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ bhattena nimanteti.
ud2.8:6.7.eng: She invites the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha to a meal for seven days.

ud2.8:6.8.pli: Adhivāsetu kira, bhante, bhagavā suppavāsāya koliyadhītāya satta bhattāni saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā’”ti.
ud2.8:6.8.eng: Sir, might the Buddha please accept seven meals from Suppavāsā.’”

ud2.8:7.1.pli: “Paraman”ti kho so koliyaputto suppavāsāya koliyadhītāya paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
ud2.8:7.1.eng: “Excellent idea,” he replied. He went to the Buddha, told him the good news, and conveyed his wife’s invitation.

ud2.8:7.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so koliyaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

ud2.8:8.1.pli: “Suppavāsā, bhante, koliyadhītā bhagavato pāde sirasā vandati;

ud2.8:8.3.pli: ‘suppavāsā, bhante, koliyadhītā satta vassāni gabbhaṃ dhāreti.

ud2.8:8.4.pli: Sattāhaṃ mūḷhagabbhā sā etarahi sukhinī arogā arogaṃ puttaṃ vijātā.

ud2.8:8.5.pli: Sā sattāhaṃ buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ bhattena nimanteti.

ud2.8:8.6.pli: Adhivāsetu kira, bhante, bhagavā suppavāsāya koliyadhītāya satta bhattāni saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā’”ti.

ud2.8:9.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarena upāsakena buddhappamukho bhikkhusaṅgho svātanāya bhattena nimantito hoti.
ud2.8:9.1.eng: Now at that time a certain lay follower had already invited the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha for the meal on the following day.

ud2.8:9.2.pli: So ca upāsako āyasmato mahāmoggallānassa upaṭṭhāko hoti.
ud2.8:9.2.eng: That lay follower was Venerable Mahāmoggallāna’s supporter.

ud2.8:9.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ āmantesi:
ud2.8:9.3.eng: Then the Buddha addressed Venerable Mahāmoggallāna,

ud2.8:9.4.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, moggallāna, yena so upāsako tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ upāsakaṃ evaṃ vadehi:
ud2.8:9.4.eng: “Please, Moggallāna, go to that lay follower and say to him,

ud2.8:9.5.pli: ‘suppavāsā, āvuso, koliyadhītā satta vassāni gabbhaṃ dhāresi.
ud2.8:9.5.eng: ‘Suppavāsā the Koliyan, who was pregnant for seven years, and in obstructed labor for seven days,

ud2.8:9.6.pli: Sattāhaṃ mūḷhagabbhā sā etarahi sukhinī arogā arogaṃ puttaṃ vijātā.
ud2.8:9.6.eng: is now happy and healthy and has given birth to a healthy child.

ud2.8:9.7.pli: Sā sattāhaṃ buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ bhattena nimanteti.
ud2.8:9.7.eng: She invites the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha to a meal for seven days.

ud2.8:9.8.pli: Karotu suppavāsā koliyadhītā satta bhattāni, pacchā tvaṃ karissasī’ti.
ud2.8:9.8.eng: Let Suppavāsā make seven meals, afterwards you can make yours.’

ud2.8:10.1.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhagavato paṭissutvā yena so upāsako tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṃ upāsakaṃ etadavoca:
ud2.8:10.1.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Mahāmoggallāna. He went to that lay follower and conveyed the Buddha’s request.

ud2.8:10.2.pli: “suppavāsā, āvuso, koliyadhītā satta vassāni gabbhaṃ dhāreti.

ud2.8:10.3.pli: Sattāhaṃ mūḷhagabbhā sā etarahi sukhinī arogā arogaṃ puttaṃ vijātā.

ud2.8:10.4.pli: Sā sattāhaṃ buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ bhattena nimanteti.

ud2.8:10.5.pli: Karotu suppavāsā koliyadhītā satta bhattāni, pacchā tvaṃ karissasī”ti.

ud2.8:11.1.pli: “Sace me, bhante, ayyo mahāmoggallāno tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ pāṭibhogo—
ud2.8:11.1.eng: “If, sir, Master Mahāmoggallāna can guarantee me three things—

ud2.8:11.3.pli: karotu suppavāsā koliyadhītā satta bhattāni, pacchāhaṃ karissāmī”ti.
ud2.8:11.3.eng: then let Suppavāsā make seven meals, afterwards I shall make mine.”

ud2.8:11.4.pli: “Dvinnaṃ kho te ahaṃ, āvuso, dhammānaṃ pāṭibhogo—

ud2.8:11.6.eng: But as for faith, you alone are the guarantor.”

ud2.8:12.1.pli: “Sace me, bhante, ayyo mahāmoggallāno dvinnaṃ dhammānaṃ pāṭibhogo—
ud2.8:12.1.eng: “If, sir Master Mahāmoggallāna can guarantee me two things—

ud2.8:12.3.pli: karotu suppavāsā koliyadhītā satta bhattāni, pacchāhaṃ karissāmī”ti.
ud2.8:12.3.eng: then let Suppavāsā make seven meals, afterwards I shall make mine.”

ud2.8:13.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno taṃ upāsakaṃ saññāpetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
ud2.8:13.1.eng: Having persuaded that lay follower, Mahāmoggallāna went to the Buddha and said,

ud2.8:13.3.pli: karotu suppavāsā koliyadhītā satta bhattāni, pacchā so karissatī”ti.
ud2.8:13.3.eng: Let Suppavāsā make seven meals, afterwards he shall make his.”

ud2.8:14.1.pli: Atha kho suppavāsā koliyadhītā sattāhaṃ buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi,
ud2.8:14.1.eng: For seven days Suppavāsā served and satisfied the Buddha with her own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.

ud2.8:14.2.pli: tañca dārakaṃ bhagavantaṃ vandāpesi sabbañca bhikkhusaṅghaṃ.
ud2.8:14.2.eng: And she made her little boy bow to the Buddha and the mendicant Sangha.

ud2.8:15.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto taṃ dārakaṃ etadavoca:
ud2.8:15.1.eng: Then Sāriputta said to the boy,

ud2.8:15.2.pli: “kacci te, dāraka, khamanīyaṃ, kacci yāpanīyaṃ, kacci na kiñci dukkhan”ti?
ud2.8:15.2.eng: “I hope you’re keeping well, little boy; I hope you’re all right. I hope that you are not in pain.”

ud2.8:15.3.pli: “Kuto me, bhante sāriputta, khamanīyaṃ, kuto yāpanīyaṃ.
ud2.8:15.3.eng: “How could I be keeping well? How could I be getting by?

ud2.8:15.4.eng: For seven years I lived in a pot of blood.”
ud2.8:15.4.comm: Lohitakumbhiya is probably a play on the common phrase lohakumbhiya, “copper pot”, which is commonly used in descriptions of hell. The boy, it seems, had an unusually rapid linguistic development.

ud2.8:16.2.pli: “putto me dhammasenāpatinā saddhiṃ mantetī”ti attamanā pamuditā pītisomanassajātā ahosi.
ud2.8:16.2.eng: “My child is conversing with the General of the Dhamma!” was uplifted and overjoyed, full of rapture and happiness.

ud2.8:16.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā suppavāsaṃ koliyadhītaraṃ attamanaṃ pamuditaṃ pītisomanassajātaṃ viditvā suppavāsaṃ koliyadhītaraṃ etadavoca:
ud2.8:16.3.eng: Knowing this, the Buddha said to her,

ud2.8:16.4.eng: “Would you like to have another child like this?”

ud2.8:16.5.eng: “Sir, I would like to have seven more children like this!”

ud2.8:17.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud2.8:17.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud2.8:18.2.eng: the disliked in the guise of the liked,

ud2.8:18.3.eng: suffering in the guise of happiness,

ud2.9:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde.
ud2.9:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery.

ud2.9:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena visākhāya migāramātuyā kocideva attho raññe pasenadimhi kosale paṭibaddho hoti.
ud2.9:1.3.eng: Now at that time Visākhā was caught up in some business with King Pasenadi.

ud2.9:1.4.pli: Taṃ rājā pasenadi kosalo na yathādhippāyaṃ tīreti.
ud2.9:1.4.eng: But the king’s settlement did not meet her expectations.

ud2.9:2.1.pli: Atha kho visākhā migāramātā divā divassa yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
ud2.9:2.1.eng: Then, in the middle of the day, she went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.

ud2.9:2.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho visākhaṃ migāramātaraṃ bhagavā etadavoca:

ud2.9:2.3.pli: “handa kuto nu tvaṃ, visākhe, āgacchasi divā divassā”ti?
ud2.9:2.3.eng: “So, Visākhā, where are you coming from in the middle of the day?”

ud2.9:2.4.pli: “Idha me, bhante, kocideva attho raññe pasenadimhi kosale paṭibaddho;
ud2.9:2.4.eng: “Sir, I am caught up in some business with King Pasenadi.

ud2.9:2.5.pli: taṃ rājā pasenadi kosalo na yathādhippāyaṃ tīretī”ti.
ud2.9:2.5.eng: But the king’s settlement did not meet my expectations.”

ud2.9:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud2.9:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud2.9:4.2.eng: all under one’s own authority is pleasing;

ud2.9:4.3.eng: what’s shared is stressful for both parties,

ud2.9:4.4.eng: for yokes are hard to escape.”

ud3.1:0.2.eng: Born of the Fruits of Deeds

ud3.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud3.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud3.1:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro bhikkhu bhagavato avidūre nisinno hoti pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya purāṇakammavipākajaṃ dukkhaṃ tibbaṃ kharaṃ kaṭukaṃ vedanaṃ adhivāsento sato sampajāno avihaññamāno.
ud3.1:1.3.eng: Now, at that time a certain mendicant was sitting not far from the Buddha, cross-legged, with his body straight. As a result of past deeds, he suffered painful, sharp, severe, and acute feelings, which he endured unbothered, with mindfulness and awareness.

ud3.1:2.1.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā taṃ bhikkhuṃ avidūre nisinnaṃ pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya purāṇakammavipākajaṃ dukkhaṃ tibbaṃ kharaṃ kaṭukaṃ vedanaṃ adhivāsentaṃ sataṃ sampajānaṃ avihaññamānaṃ.
ud3.1:2.1.eng: The Buddha saw him meditating and enduring that pain.

ud3.1:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud3.1:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud3.1:4.1.eng: “A mendicant who has left all deeds behind,

ud3.1:4.2.eng: shaking off the dust of past deeds,

ud3.10:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā uruvelāyaṃ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre bodhirukkhamūle paṭhamābhisambuddho.
ud3.10:1.2.eng: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying in Uruvelā at the root of the tree of awakening on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.

ud3.10:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā sattāhaṃ ekapallaṅkena nisinno hoti vimuttisukhapaṭisaṃvedī.
ud3.10:1.3.eng: There the Buddha sat cross-legged for seven days without moving, experiencing the bliss of freedom.

ud3.10:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassa sattāhassa accayena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhahitvā buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ volokesi.
ud3.10:2.1.eng: When seven days had passed, the Buddha emerged from that state of immersion and surveyed the world with the eye of a Buddha.

ud3.10:2.2.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā buddhacakkhunā volokento satte anekehi santāpehi santappamāne, anekehi ca pariḷāhehi pariḍayhamāne—
ud3.10:2.2.eng: He saw sentient beings tormented with many torments, and burning with many fevers

ud3.10:2.3.eng: born of greed, hate, and delusion.

ud3.10:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud3.10:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud3.10:4.2.eng: overcome by contact, speaks of disease as the self.

ud3.10:4.3.eng: For whatever it thinks it is,

ud3.10:4.4.eng: it turns out to be something else.

ud3.10:5.1.eng: The world is attached to continued existence, <j>overcome by continued existence,

ud3.10:5.2.eng: taking pleasure only in continued existence, <j>yet it becomes something else.

ud3.10:5.3.eng: What it enjoys, that is the fear;

ud3.10:5.4.eng: what it fears, that is the suffering.

ud3.10:5.5.eng: But this spiritual life is led

ud3.10:5.6.eng: in order to give up continued existence.

ud3.10:6.1.pli: ‘Ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā bhavena bhavassa vippamokkhamāhaṃsu, sabbe te avippamuttā bhavasmā’ti vadāmi.
ud3.10:6.1.eng: Of the ascetics and brahmins who say that through continued existence one is freed from continued existence, none are themselves freed from continued existence, I say.

ud3.10:6.2.pli: ‘Ye vā pana keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā vibhavena bhavassa nissaraṇamāhaṃsu, sabbe te anissaṭā bhavasmā’ti vadāmi.
ud3.10:6.2.eng: Of the ascetics and brahmins who say that through nonexistence one escapes from existence, none have themselves escaped from existence, I say.

ud3.10:7.1.pli: Upadhiñhi paṭicca dukkhamidaṃ sambhoti, sabbupādānakkhayā natthi dukkhassa sambhavo.
ud3.10:7.1.eng: For this suffering originates dependent on all attachment. With the ending of all grasping there is no origination of suffering.
ud3.10:7.1.comm: Thai editions read sabbupadhiṁ hi, which is supported by the Udānavarga.

ud3.10:7.3.pli: puthū avijjāya paretā bhūtā bhūtaratā aparimuttā;
ud3.10:7.3.eng: Mired in all sorts of ignorance, beings in love with being are not released from continued existence.
ud3.10:7.3.comm: Accepting bhavā aparimuttā from the Buddha Jayanthi edition. For puthu, the commentary says bahū, visuṁ visuṁ vā.

ud3.10:7.4.pli: ye hi keci bhavā sabbadhi sabbatthatāya sabbe te bhavā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammāti.
ud3.10:7.4.eng: Whatever states of continued existence there are—everywhere, all over—all are impermanent, suffering, and perishable.

ud3.10:8.1.eng: One who sees truly like this,

ud3.10:8.3.eng: gives up craving for continued existence,

ud3.10:8.4.eng: while not looking forward to nonexistence.

ud3.10:8.5.eng: Extinguishment comes <j>from the ending of all cravings;

ud3.10:8.6.eng: fading away and cessation with nothing left over.

ud3.10:9.2.eng: for that mendicant extinguished without grasping.

ud3.10:9.3.eng: Victorious in battle, such a one has defeated Māra;

ud3.10:9.4.eng: they’ve gone beyond all states of existence.”

ud3.2:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
ud3.2:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

ud3.2:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā nando bhagavato bhātā mātucchāputto sambahulānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ evamāroceti:
ud3.2:1.3.eng: Now at that time Venerable Nanda, the Buddha’s brother and maternal cousin, informed several mendicants:

ud3.2:1.5.pli: na sakkomi brahmacariyaṃ sandhāretuṃ, sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissāmī”ti.
ud3.2:1.5.eng: I am unable to keep up the spiritual life. I shall resign the training and return to a lesser life.”

ud3.2:2.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
ud3.2:2.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.

ud3.2:2.2.pli: “āyasmā, bhante, nando bhagavato bhātā mātucchāputto sambahulānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ evamāroceti:

ud3.2:2.3.pli: ‘anabhirato ahaṃ, āvuso, brahmacariyaṃ carāmi, na sakkomi brahmacariyaṃ sandhāretuṃ, sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissāmī’”ti.

ud3.2:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ āmantesi:
ud3.2:3.1.eng: So the Buddha addressed one of the monks,

ud3.2:3.2.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mama vacanena nandaṃ bhikkhuṃ āmantehi:
ud3.2:3.2.eng: “Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicant Nanda that

ud3.2:3.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato paṭissutvā yenāyasmā nando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ nandaṃ etadavoca:
ud3.2:3.4.eng: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Nanda and said to him,

ud3.2:4.1.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā nando tassa bhikkhuno paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ nandaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
ud3.2:4.1.eng: “Yes, reverend,” Nanda replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

ud3.2:5.1.pli: “Saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, nanda, sambahulānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ evamārocesi:
ud3.2:5.1.eng: “Is it really true, Nanda, that you informed several mendicants that

ud3.2:5.2.pli: ‘anabhirato ahaṃ, āvuso, brahmacariyaṃ carāmi, na sakkomi brahmacariyaṃ sandhāretuṃ, sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissāmī’”ti?
ud3.2:5.2.eng: you are unable to keep up the spiritual life; that you shall resign the training and return to a lesser life?”

ud3.2:6.1.pli: “Kissa pana tvaṃ, nanda, anabhirato brahmacariyaṃ carasi, na sakkosi brahmacariyaṃ sandhāretuṃ, sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissasī”ti?
ud3.2:6.1.eng: “But why are you so dissatisfied with the spiritual life?”

ud3.2:6.2.pli: “Sākiyānī maṃ, bhante, janapadakalyāṇī gharā nikkhamantassa upaḍḍhullikhitehi kesehi apaloketvā maṃ etadavoca:
ud3.2:6.2.eng: “As I left my house, sir, the finest lady of the Sakyan land, her hair half-combed, glanced at me and said,

ud3.2:6.4.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhante, tamanussaramāno anabhirato brahmacariyaṃ carāmi, na sakkomi brahmacariyaṃ sandhāretuṃ, sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissāmī”ti.
ud3.2:6.4.eng: Recalling that, I am dissatisfied and shall resign the training.”

ud3.2:7.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ nandaṃ bāhāyaṃ gahetvā—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evamevaṃ—jetavane antarahito devesu tāvatiṃsesu pāturahosi.
ud3.2:7.1.eng: Then the Buddha took Nanda by the arm and, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from Jeta’s Grove and reappeared among the gods of the thirty-three.

ud3.2:8.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena pañcamattāni accharāsatāni sakkassa devānamindassa upaṭṭhānaṃ āgatāni honti kakuṭapādāni.
ud3.2:8.1.eng: Now at that time five hundred dove-footed nymphs had come to attend to Sakka, the lord of gods.
ud3.2:8.1.comm: The image of the “dove-footed” nymphs is, so far as I know, unique. Doves have bright pink feet, evoking the rouged feet often mentioned as a sign of beauty. But doves in Vedic mythology are emissaries of  Nirṛti, the malign goddess of dissolution. The footprint of a dove in the fireplace is an omen of death (Rig Veda 10.165.4,  Āpastamba Gṛhyasūtra 8.23.9). Perhaps these delightful nymphs are the secret emissaries of Dissolution, their feet betraying the horrifying reality beneath the beguiling surface.

ud3.2:8.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ nandaṃ āmantesi:
ud3.2:8.2.eng: Then the Buddha said to Nanda,

ud3.2:8.3.pli: “passasi no tvaṃ, nanda, imāni pañca accharāsatāni kakuṭapādānī”ti?
ud3.2:8.3.eng: “Nanda, do you see these five hundred dove-footed nymphs?”

ud3.2:9.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, nanda, katamā nu kho abhirūpatarā vā dassanīyatarā vā pāsādikatarā vā, sākiyānī vā janapadakalyāṇī, imāni vā pañca accharāsatāni kakuṭapādānī”ti?
ud3.2:9.1.eng: “What do you think, Nanda? Who is more attractive, good-looking, and lovely—the finest lady of the Sakyan land, or these five hundred dove-footed nymphs?”

ud3.2:9.2.eng: “Compared to these five hundred dove-footed nymphs, the finest lady of the Sakyan land is like a deformed monkey with its ears and nose cut off.

ud3.2:9.3.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhante, sākiyānī janapadakalyāṇī imesaṃ pañcannaṃ accharāsatānaṃ upanidhāya saṅkhyampi nopeti kalabhāgampi nopeti upanidhimpi nopeti.
ud3.2:9.3.eng: She doesn’t count, there’s no comparison, she’s not worth a fraction.

ud3.2:9.4.pli: Atha kho imāni pañca accharāsatāni abhirūpatarāni ceva dassanīyatarāni ca pāsādikatarāni cā”ti.
ud3.2:9.4.eng: These five hundred dove-footed nymphs are far more attractive, good-looking, and lovely.”

ud3.2:10.2.pli: Ahaṃ te pāṭibhogo pañcannaṃ accharāsatānaṃ paṭilābhāya kakuṭapādānan”ti.
ud3.2:10.2.eng: I guarantee you five hundred dove-footed nymphs.”

ud3.2:10.3.pli: “Sace me, bhante, bhagavā pāṭibhogo pañcannaṃ accharāsatānaṃ paṭilābhāya kakuṭapādānaṃ, abhiramissāmahaṃ, bhante, bhagavati brahmacariye”ti.
ud3.2:10.3.eng: “If, sir, you guarantee me five hundred dove-footed nymphs, I shall happily lead the spiritual life under the Buddha.”

ud3.2:11.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ nandaṃ bāhāyaṃ gahetvā—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evamevaṃ—devesu tāvatiṃsesu antarahito jetavane pāturahosi.
ud3.2:11.1.eng: Then the Buddha took Nanda by the arm and, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from the gods of the thirty-three and reappeared at Jeta’s Grove.

ud3.2:12.2.pli: “āyasmā kira nando bhagavato bhātā mātucchāputto accharānaṃ hetu brahmacariyaṃ carati;
ud3.2:12.2.eng: “It seems Venerable Nanda—who is both the Buddha’s half-brother and maternal cousin—leads the spiritual life for the sake of nymphs.

ud3.2:12.3.pli: bhagavā kirassa pāṭibhogo pañcannaṃ accharāsatānaṃ paṭilābhāya kakuṭapādānan”ti.
ud3.2:12.3.eng: And it seems that the Buddha guaranteed him five hundred dove-footed nymphs.”

ud3.2:13.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmato nandassa sahāyakā bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ nandaṃ bhatakavādena ca upakkitakavādena ca samudācaranti:
ud3.2:13.1.eng: Monks who were his friends accused him of being a hireling and a lackey,

ud3.2:13.2.pli: “bhatako kirāyasmā nando upakkitako kirāyasmā nando accharānaṃ hetu brahmacariyaṃ carati;
ud3.2:13.2.eng: “It seems Nanda is a hireling, it seems he is a lackey: he leads the spiritual life for the sake of nymphs.

ud3.2:13.3.pli: bhagavā kirassa pāṭibhogo pañcannaṃ accharāsatānaṃ paṭilābhāya kakuṭapādānan”ti.
ud3.2:13.3.eng: And it seems that the Buddha guaranteed him five hundred dove-footed nymphs.”

ud3.2:14.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā nando sahāyakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ bhatakavādena ca upakkitakavādena ca aṭṭīyamāno harāyamāno jigucchamāno eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
ud3.2:14.1.eng: Then Nanda—embarrassed, ashamed, and disgusted at being called a hireling and a lackey—living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

ud3.2:14.2.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
ud3.2:14.2.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

ud3.2:14.3.pli: Aññataro kho panāyasmā nando arahataṃ ahosi.
ud3.2:14.3.eng: Venerable Nanda became one of the perfected.

ud3.2:15.1.pli: Atha kho aññatarā devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho sā devatā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
ud3.2:15.1.eng: Then, late at night, a glorious deity, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him:

ud3.2:15.2.pli: “āyasmā, bhante, nando bhagavato bhātā mātucchāputto āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī”ti.
ud3.2:15.2.eng: “Sir, Venerable Nanda—who is both the Buddha’s half-brother and maternal cousin—has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. He lives having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements.”

ud3.2:15.3.eng: And the knowledge also came to the Buddha:

ud3.2:15.4.pli: “nando āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī”ti.
ud3.2:15.4.eng: “Nanda has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. He lives having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements.”

ud3.2:16.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā nando tassā rattiyā accayena yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā nando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
ud3.2:16.1.eng: Then, when the night had passed, Nanda went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

ud3.2:16.2.pli: “yaṃ me, bhante, bhagavā pāṭibhogo pañcannaṃ accharāsatānaṃ paṭilābhāya kakuṭapādānaṃ, muñcāmahaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ etasmā paṭissavā”ti.
ud3.2:16.2.eng: “Worthy sir, you guaranteed me five hundred dove-footed nymphs. I release you from that promise.”

ud3.2:16.3.pli: “Mayāpi kho tvaṃ, nanda, cetasā ceto paricca vidito:
ud3.2:16.3.eng: “Nanda, I encompassed your mind and knew that

ud3.2:16.4.pli: ‘nando āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī’ti.
ud3.2:16.4.eng: you had realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom.

ud3.2:16.5.eng: And deities also told me about this.

ud3.2:16.6.pli: ‘āyasmā, bhante, nando bhagavato bhātā mātucchāputto āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī’ti.

ud3.2:16.7.pli: Yadeva kho te, nanda, anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuttaṃ, athāhaṃ mutto etasmā paṭissavā”ti.
ud3.2:16.7.eng: As soon as your mind was freed from defilements by not grasping, I was released from that promise.”

ud3.2:17.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
ud3.2:17.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

ud3.2:18.1.eng: “The mendicant who has crossed over the bog,

ud3.2:18.2.eng: who has crushed the thorn of sensuality,

ud3.2:18.3.eng: who has reached the end of delusion,

ud3.2:18.4.eng: trembles not at pleasure and pain.”
